Note...
The term 
“circulation”
 refers to the 
long-term average
 
pattern of atmospheric winds and ocean currents

Wind belts alternate direction

Observed Ocean Surface Salinity
1.
Saltiest water in the 
subtropics


2.
Atlantic considerably 
more salty than the 
other oceans


3.
North Pacific is 
among the freshest of 
all regions

1. High salinity in surface 
layer in subtropics


2. Deep-ocean salinity 
more uniform and 
generally matches the

1.
Lar
ge subtropical gyres
  rotating 
clockwise in the northern 
hemisphere and counter-clockwise 
in the southern hemisphere.
2.
Subpolar gyres rotating 
counterclockwise in the 
northern 
hemisphere and absent in the 
southern hemisphere
3.
Antarctic Circumpolar Current 
moving eastward around the 
Antarctic Continent.
Observed Surface Ocean Currents

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Observed Deep Ocean Circulation
1. Cold surface water sinks 
specifically at high 
latitudes and moves to 
lower latitudes at depth.


2. Deep-water returned to 
the surface layer through 
broad diffusive upward 
vertical mixing

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section II
The Coriolis Force

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Sir Isaac Newton’s famous “F=ma” law only works for a 
reference coordinate system that is at rest
 (or at the very 
least not accelerating). 


2.
When the reference frame is itself accelerating (e.g., a 
car 
turning a corner, a rotating merry-go-round or a rotating 
earth
), then 
the acceleration of the reference frame itself 
must also be taken into account. 
3.
Before Newton’s Law can be used, a Coriolis force is needed to 
account for the acceleration of the reference coordinate system 
(
i.e., for the angular acceleration of the latitude longitude grid on 
a rotating earth
)
The Need for a Coriolis Force...
Sir Isaac Newton
 
1642-1727
Gustave Gaspard de Coriolis 
1792-1843

© 2023 Bruce Monger
A Qualitative Description of 
the Coriolis Force
1.
Northward movement of a 
water parcel 
(
green circle
) 
brings it closer to the axis of rotation. 


2.
Based on the need for the 
conservation of angular 
momentum,
 the water parcel must spin faster around 
axis of rotation (i.e., eastward).
•
a close analogy
 to this process is an ice skater that spins faster when 
they draw their hands close to their body.
 
3.
If the earth is treated as a non-rotating reference frame (which is what we 
want to do) then an 
apparent force
 
(blue arrows) must be added 
to explain 
the apparent push on the parcel in the eastward direction - this apparent force 
is the Coriolis Force!


4.
The eastward-directed Coriolis Force in this northern hemisphere example is 
also viewed as an apparent force
 directed to the right of northward motion
.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Eastward movement of a water parcel (green circle) 
causes the parcel to spin faster around the axis of 
rotation and this generates an 
outward-directed 
centrifugal force
 (
blue arrows
).
3.
The Coriolis force
 (
blue arrows
) is the 
apparent force 
that is needed to explain the apparent 
southward push on the parcel in the case where the earth is treated as a non-spinning (non-
accelerating) reference frame. 
•
a close analogy
 to this process is a pail of water being swung around in 
a circle giving rise to an outward-directed force on the water in the pail.  


2.
The centrifugal force acting on the parcel of ocean water in the northern 
hemisphere pushes it southward -
 which is to the right of its initial motion.
 
A Qualitative Description of 
the Coriolis Force

© 2023 Bruce Monger
All You Really Need to Know About the Coriolis 
Force For This Class...
1.
It arises from real physics related to the conservation of angular moment


2.
In the 
northern hemisphere
 the Coriolis Force is always directed to the 
right
 of 
the water parcel motion


3.
In the 
southern hemisphere
 the Coriolis Force is always directed to the 
left
 of the 
water parcel motion


4.
The Basic Rule
 to determine the direction of the Coriolis Force is to 
1)
point your nose
 in the direction the ocean current (or wind) is moving


2)
then stick your hand directly out from your side 
to get the direction of the Coriolis 
force – use the 
right hand
 for the northern hemisphere or use the 
left hand
 for the 
southern hemisphere

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Atmospheric Circulation
Section III

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Material is warmed when it absorbs radiant energy
 
 
e.g., a black shirt that absorbs radiant sunlight energy
2.
Much of the visible radiant energy from the sun (
referred to 
as 
short
 wavelength radiation
) passes right through the 
atmosphere 
without being absorbed
 and, consequently, 
without much direct heating of the atmosphere from the sun.
3.
The earth’s surface absorbs a lot of the short wavelength 
sunlight energy
 and so it becomes warm.
4.
The warm earth surface radiates infrared radiation (
referred 
to as 
long
 wavelength radiation
) from its surface and 
this 
energy 
is absorbed
 
by the atmosphere and, consequently 
warms the atmosphere.
5.
So the atmosphere is heated from below
 
by 
absorbing 
long wavelength radiation
 emitted from the 
warm earth surface
.
Atmospheric Heating

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Atmospheric Convection
1.
The warm ocean surface heats the 
atmosphere from below


2.
Warm surface air is able to hold a lot of 
water vapor and so it becomes moist.


3.
Warm moist surface air has low density so it 
rises (like a hot air balloon) and as it moves 
higher it expands and cools


4.
Cooling of air aloft causes water vapor to 
condense and precipitate 


5.
Condensation releases latent heat that 
warms the surrounding air and drives the 
upward convection even higher

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Solar Heating of the Earth Surface
1.
Solar heating of the earth 
surface is most intense at the 
equator where the solar 
radiation is most direct.


2.
Consequently, atmospheric 
convection and precipitation 
is strongest along the equator

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Intertropical Convergence Zone  
The ITCZ
1.Strong surface heating by the 
sun along the equator drives 
upward atmospheric 
convection, condensation and 
precipitation.


2.The result is an obvious band 
of thick clouds that forms 
along the equator


3.This region migrates north 
and south seasonally with the 
summer/winter movement of 
the sun overhead

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Idealized Hadley Circulation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
But First... A Question...
Background:
 The weight of a column of air is directly proportional to the average molecular 
weight of the mix of all molecules making up the air in the air column.  The atmosphere is 
composed mostly of N
2
 (78%) and O
2
 (21%). Water vapor (H
2
O ) in the lower atmosphere is 
variable (<1% up to about 4%).


Assume dry air is composed of just nitrogen gas (
N
2
 with a molecular weight of 
28
) with some 
variable amount of water vapor gas (
H
2
O
 with a molecular weight of 
18
). 
Which type of air column would weigh less??? 
 
i.e., produces lower sea level pressure underneath it??? 
a)
a column of 
dry air 
b)
a column of air with 
high amounts of water vapor.
The 
correct answer is (b)
 since the average molecular weight of the mixture of 
molecules making up the air column is on average lower when overall fraction of 
water vapor gas is high.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Idealized Hadley 
Circulation
Low SLP
High SLP
High SLP
Low SLP
2.
Warn and Dry Surface air at 30°
 spreads out north and south, picks up moisture - by 60° 
latitude it has moistened to the point where it rises, cools, precipitates and spreads out aloft 
north/south. 


3.
Near the poles
 the air aloft becomes very cold and very dense so it sinks over the poles and 
spreads out toward the equator
SLP= Sea Level Pressure
1.
Surface air at the 
equator
 warms and rises 
aloft.  The air aloft spreads 
north/south and becomes 
more dense as it cools and 
dries (due to precipitation) 
and then sinks and warms 
at about 30° latitude.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Global Sea Level Pressure Resulting from Idealized Hadley Circulation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
3-D View of 
Idealized Hadley 
Circulation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Idealized Versus Actual Pattern of Global Sea Level 
Pressure And Resulting Surface Winds
1.
Differences due to unequal 
warming of land and 
ocean by the sun


2.
Land warms more strongly 
than adjacent ocean in 
summer and cools more 
deeply than adjacent 
ocean in winter - due to 
differences in specific heat 
of rock versus seawater.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Vertical Distribution of Seawater Density
Section IV

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Why worry about the vertical distribution of 
seawater density in the ocean?
Vertical distribution of density directly influences the vertical 
movement of water in the ocean.
Salt concentration
 and 
water temperature
 jointly determine 
seawater density
, consequently, the concepts of ocean salinity and 
ocean heat content are presented in some detail.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Surface Salinity

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Parts per Thousand
Ocean Surface 
Salinity
Much more will be said later in 
the semester.  For now, just 
know that salinity is set at the 
ocean surface as a result of 
the exchange of fresh water 
between the ocean and 
atmosphere through the 
processes of 
evaporation
 and 
precipitation
. 


Rain lowers ocean salt 
concentration. Evaporation 
raises salt concentration.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Surface Ocean Temperature is Determined by the Exchange of 
Heat Across the Air-Sea Boundary

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Main Heat Flux Components In 
and Out of the Surface Ocean
1.
Ocean temperature is a measure of the 
heat energy contained in the ocean.


2.
When more energy enters than leaves 
the ocean surface, the ocean surface 
warms. Similarly, when more heat 
leaves than enters the ocean surface, 
the ocean surface cools.
 
3.
Sunlight energy 
always adds heat to 
the ocean
 (during daylight hours).
4.
There are lots of ways to lose heat with Evaporative Cooling often being the dominant method of heat 
loss in most cases.


5.
For temperate (mid-latitude) ocean regions
 in spring/summer
, more heat enters the ocean from 
sunlight than leaves the ocean and so the surface ocean warms.  
In winter,
 more heat leaves than 
comes in from sunlight and so the surface ocean cools.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Depth of Light Penetration Into the Surface Ocean Is 
Relatively Shallow
1.
In the clearest open-ocean 
waters: Light penetrates (at 
most) down to about 150-200 
meters 


2.
In turbid coastal waters: light 
may only penetrate a few 
meters to perhaps 50 meters


3.
Most of the overall heating 
occurs in less than 20-30 
meters.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Because most of the sunlight energy is quickly absorbed in the 
ocean, all 
direct solar heating takes place very near the 
ocean surface (0-30 meters).  


2.
Vertical mixing of near-surface water
 can move some of the 
warm water deeper, but mixing only reaches at most to about 
500 meters.  


3.
Seawater below 500 meters is uniformly cold.


4.
The broad region centered at around 500 meters where 
seawater temperature changes from warm to uniformly cold is 
referred to as the 
permanent thermocline
 


5.
In some ocean regions, there is a much shallower thermocline that 
only forms in summer and is then erased in winter. This temporary 
thermocline is referred to as the 
seasonal thermocline
Typical Vertical Profile 
of Temperature

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
In a 
stably stratified
 ocean, less dense water 
“floats” above more dense water.


2.
The 
seasonal pycnocline
 (
a region of strong 
change in density with depth
) comes and 
goes with net heat gains in spring and summer 
and net heat losses in fall and winter


3.
The 
permanent pycnocline
 remains in place (at 
around 500 meters) and is the result of the long-
term balance between the downward heating/
mixing at the surface and upward mixing of cold 
water from below.
Typical Vertical Density 
Profile

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Seasonal Thermocline

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Main Heat Flux Components In 
and Out of the Surface Ocean
1.
Ocean temperature is a measure of 
the heat energy contained in the 
ocean.


2.
When more energy enters than 
leaves the ocean surface, the 
ocean surface warms. Similarly, 
when more heat leaves than 
enters the ocean surface, the 
ocean surface cools.
 
3.
Sunlight energy 
always adds heat 
to the ocean 
(during daylight 
hours).
4.
There are lots of ways to lose heat with Evaporative Cooling often being the dominant method of heat loss 


5.
For temperate (mid-latitude) ocean regions
 
in spring/summer
, 
more heat enters the ocean from 
sunlight than leaves the ocean and so the surface ocean warms.  
In winter, 
more heat leaves than comes 
in from sunlight and so the surface ocean cools.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Seasonal Variation of Heating and Cooling of the Surface 
Ocean 
at Mid-Latitude Regions

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Annual Range of Sea Surface Temperature

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Seasonal Change in Surface Layer 
Temperature
 and Surface 
Layer 
Thickness

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Cartoon Depicting the Latitudinal Range of the Seasonal 
and Permanent Thermocline

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Wind-Driven Ocean Currents
Section V

© 2023 Bruce Monger
But First...
Two Foundational Concepts 
Need to be Developed Before I 
Can Describe How The Wind 
Drives the Surface Ocean 
Currents of the Very Large 
Subtropical Gyres
Where we are headed...
The Two Foundational Concepts Are: 
1.
Ekman Transport 
2.
Geostrophic Currents

© 2023 Bruce Monger
4.
Ekman Transport: 
is the rate of 
total water
 transported in the 
Ekman Layer (a layer that is 
about 50 to 100 meters thick) 
5.
Derived by summing all the individual thin currents sheets over the entire Ekman Layer


6.
Ekman Transport is exactly at 90 degrees from the wind direction


7.
Oceanographers often treat the Ekman Layer as a slab of water (i.e., the Ekman Layer) that 
moves in unison at 90 degrees to the right (northern hemisphere) or left (southern 
hemisphere) of the wind direct 
Ekman Layer
1.
Ekman Spiral
:  the spiraling of thin ocean 
currents within the Ekman Layer


2.
top-most current moves at 45-degrees to the 
wind forcing. Because of 
Wind+Coriolis+Friction  
3.
The bottom-most current moves directly 
opposite the wind direction. 
Ekman Transport Due to Wind Force, 
Friction Force and Coriolis Force

© 2023 Bruce Monger
3.
The fluid continues to be pushed by Coriolis until the Coriolis force is directed equal and opposite of the 
pressure gradient force - at which point the two forces cancel and the fluid move at steady speed (no 
acceleration) - remember too that there is no friction to bring this steady motion to a halt!


4.
The point at which currents move with steady speed, 
with Coriolis and pressure gradient forces in prefect 
opposition
, is referred to as 
geostrophic balance
 and the resulting current is referred to as a 
geostrophic 
current
.
 
5.
Notice that 
fully developed geostrophic currents
 
move along lines of constant pressure
 (black lines in 
the figure above)!! 
1.
Fluid first responds to a 
pressure gradient force
 
(
blue arrow
) and moves down the pressure 
gradient toward lower pressure


2.
Coriolis force 
(
red arrow
) always pushes the fluid 
to the right of 
its present direction of travel
Top View of Horizontal Pressure Gradient
Response of Fluid in the Ocean Due to 
Pressure Gradient Force and Coriolis Force 
a simplified example here...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Formation of Subtropical Gyres

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Dark Lines
 are 
contours of constant 
pressure
 that decrease away from the 
center of the mound region.


2.
Yellow Arrows 
are the 
direction of fluid 
motion
 (geostrophic currents) for a 
northern hemisphere mound.


3.
Light Blue Arrows
 point out the directions 
of the 
pressure gradient force
 - toward 
lower pressure


4.
Red Arrows
 point out the 
Coriolis force
 
and are directed to the right of fluid motion 
- and in this case to the center of the high 
pressure
If a mound of water builds up at the surface of the ocean, a central high pressure 
develops under the mound and circular geostrophic currents develop
Outward Pressure Gradient Force
Inward Coriolis Force

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Combining the Concepts of Ekman Transport 
and Geostrophic Currents...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Development of the Subtropical Gyre in Response to 
Forcing by the Westerly and Trade Wind Belts
1.
Westerly Winds and Trade Winds drive the Ekman 
Layer to the center of the gyre to create a mound of 
surface water 
2.
A center of high pressure develops under the mound of 
surface water.


3.
The fluid initially moves away from the center of high 
pressure


4.
The push of Coriolis turns the fluid until it travels 
along concentric lines of constant pressure - 
geostrophic balance 
5.
Note that Coriolis force always points toward the center 
of high pressure and in the northern hemisphere the right 
hand Coriolis rule then requires concentric clockwise 
motion to achieve a center directed Coriolis force.  
Counterclockwise motion is needed in the southern 
hemisphere with its left hand Coriolis Rule

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Currents on western side of 
all subtropical gyres are 
called 
Western Boundary 
Currents
 - they are 
very 
swift and narrow
 jets that 
bring warm water from the 
tropics to high latitudes 
2.
Currents on eastern side of all 
subtropical gyres are called 
Eastern Boundary 
Currents
 - they are 
broad 
and slow
 and 
bring cold 
water from the high 
latitudes toward the tropics.
Western Intensification of Gyre Circulation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Ocean and Atmosphere 
Circulation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Equatorial & Coastal Upwelling
 
A Result of Ekman Transport

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Ekman Transport: 
is the movement of a 
slab of water (Ekman Layer)
 by the 
direct action of the winds
 
— 
a layer that is 
about 50 to 100 meters thick
.


2.
Ekman Transport is exactly at 90 degrees 
from the wind direction
Ekman 
Layer
RECALL: Ekman Transport
3.
Oceanographers often treat the Ekman Layer as a slab of water (i.e., the Ekman Layer) 
that moves in unison at 90 degrees 
to the right in the northern hemisphere
 and 
to 
the left in the southern hemisphere
.

© 2022 Bruce Monger
© 2023 Bruce Monger
Equatorial Upwelling
4.
Surface water also piles up on the western side of the ocean basin forcing a downward tilt to the 
thermocline


5.
Water is drawn up from the base to the [shallow] Ekman Depth.   
• If the thermocline is close the Ekman Depth, then cold water is drawn to the surface 
• if the thermocline is deep only more warm water is drawn to the surface 
1.
North East Trade Winds drive Ekman Transport 
of the surface layer 
to the north
 
2.
South East Trade Winds drive Ekman Transport 
of the surface layer 
to the south
 
3.
The “parting” of the surface water to the north 
and south requires, by continuity, that deep 
water rises upward from the base of the Ekman 
Layer to the surface along the Equator.
Ekman Layer Depth

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Sea Surface Temperature in the Equatorial Pacific
2.
Western Equatorial 
Pacific Warm Pool -  
upwelling still occurs, but 
the thermocline is 
much deeper
 than the 
surface Ekman Depth so 
upwelling  just draws 
more    warm water to 
the surface with no 
effective cooling.
1.
Eastern Equatorial Pacific Cold Tongue -  due to equatorial upwelling AND the 
close proximity of the thermocline to surface Ekman Depth

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Coastal Upwelling Along the 
Washington Oregon Coast
1.
Wind blowing out of the north drives the 
Ekman layer to the right (northern 
hemisphere) which is 
offshore


2.
The offshore transport of the Ekman 
surface layer is replaced by 
upwelling
 
of deeper cold water along the coast 


3.
Wind blowing out of the south drives 
the Ekman Layer again to the right 
(because northern hemisphere) which is 
onshore
4.
The onshore transport of the Ekman surface layer is driven downward - a process called 
downwelling
 
Upwelling
 Favorable Winds
Downwelling 
Favorable Winds

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Deep Ocean Currents and The Conveyor Belt Circulation
Section VI

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1. Warm thin surface 
layer


2. Cold thick deep layer


3. Thermocline 
separates the warm 
and cold layers
Atlantic Ocean Temperature at Depth
 
Meridional Section from Iceland to Antarctica

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Atlantic Ocean Salinity at Depth
1.
High salinity in surface 
layer in subtropics
2.
Deep-ocean salinity 
more uniform and 
generally matches the 
surface salinity at higher 
latitude - especially 
northern high latitudes.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
NADW: 
North Atlantic Deep Water
2.
AABW:
 Antarctic Bottom Water
3.
AAIW:
 Antarctic Intermediate Water
Temperature-Salinity 
“Signatures” of the three 
Major 
Water Masses
 in 
the Global Ocean

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Water Masses of the North Atlantic

© 2023 Bruce Monger
3.
Deep water in the North Atlantic moves south and mergers with Antarctic water in the 
Southern Ocean as they both swing around Antarctica and up into the Indian and Pacific 
Ocean basin.


4.
The oldest deep waters (c.a., 2000 years) are in the deep Pacific.
1.
Cold dense water sinks in the North 
Atlantic and also around Antarctica to 
form deep abyssal water


2.
North Pacific salinity is too low to 
sink even though temperatures are 
just as cold as the North Atlantic
The Speed of Circulation 
of Deep Water in the 
Global Ocean From 
14
C 
Radioactive Decay Tracer

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Locations of Deep Water Formation in the North Atlantic
1) Labrador, 2) Irminger, 3) Greenland and 4) Norwegian Seas

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Locations of Deep 
Water Formation 
Around Antarctica
1) Ross and 2) Weddell Sea

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Global Conveyor Belt Circulation 
 
Combining the Deep Circulation and the Wind-Driven 
Surface Circulation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Conveyor Belt Circulation: 
A Super Idealized Pattern

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Conveyor Belt Circulation: 
A Heavily Idealized Pattern

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Schematic of Heat 
Transport by the Global 
Conveyor Belt Circulation
3.
After giving up heat at high latitudes, surface water sinks and enters the thermohaline deep 
circulation and eventually is returned to the surface to pick up more heat and start the 
journey all over again. 
1.
Heat is gained by the surface ocean 
at low latitudes and transported via 
the wind-driven surface circulation 
(western boundary currents) to 
higher latitudes.


2.
Heat is given up by the ocean to 
the atmosphere at higher latitudes 
to warm these regions.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Most Heat Transport to High 
Latitudes is Done by Strong 
Western Boundary Currents 
1.
Western Europe experiences mild 
winters, relative to Northern 
Canada, because the Gulf Stream 
brings warm ocean water northward 
to warm the atmosphere off the 
coast. 


2.
Westerly winds then carry the warm 
coastal air over land.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2021/feb/25/atlantic-ocean-circulation-at-weakest-in-a-millennium-say-scientists?fbclid=IwAR3k5AhLk7Ve5sx2ONXunfy6lVQhe0zyRgi8a811ngowFvyg3gAT20pYNFM
AMOC circulation is at 
its weakest level in more 
than a 1000 years.
* Atlantic Meridional
 
  Overturning Circulation (AMOC)

© 2023 Bruce Monger
AMOC Collapse
See Also: https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2021/08/05/change-ocean-collapse-atlantic-meridional/?fbclid=IwAR2EK6-lFXj_d2svD0X0UgiY39P3EBkDovtVw2Gvdz0bYvRNYnnwo6SmgWI
1.
A 2019 IPCC Special Report on the Ocean and 
Cryosphere in a Changing Climate concluded 
that the AMOC would weaken during this 
century, but total collapse within the next 300 
years was only likely under the worst-case 
warming scenarios.
2.
The recent analysis suggests that the critical threshold is closer than the 2019 IPPC Special 
Report indicted. 
3.
The “bi-stable” nature of the phenomenon means it will find a new equilibrium in its o
ff
 state and 
turning it back on would require a shift in the climate far greater than the changes that 
triggered the shutdown
.

See this excellent (
optional
) article on the recent news that the AMOC might shut down in a matter 
of a couple of decades:

A Brief Review of Ocean-Atmosphere Circulation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Sir Isaac Newton’s famous “F=ma” law only works for a 
reference 
coordinate system that is at rest
 (or at the very least not 
accelerating) 


2.
When the reference frame is itself accelerating (e.g., a 
car turning a 
corner, a rotating merry-go-round or a rotating earth
), then all 
bets are off on Newton’s simple law working 
unless the 
acceleration of the reference frame itself is also taken into 
account. 
3.
Addition of a Coriolis force is needed to account for the 
acceleration of the reference coordinate system (
i.e., for the angular 
acceleration of the latitude longitude grid on a rotating earth
) before 
Newton’s Law can be used.
The Need for a Coriolis Force...
Sir Isaac Newton
 
1642-1727
Gustave Gaspard de Coriolis 
1792-1843

© 2023 Bruce Monger
All You Really Need to Know About the 
Coriolis Force For This Class...
1.
It arises from real physics related to the conservation of angular moment


2.
In the 
northern hemisphere
 the Coriolis Force is always directed to the 
right
 of 
the water parcel motion


3.
In the 
southern hemisphere
 the Coriolis Force is always directed to the 
left
 of the 
water parcel motion


4.
The Basic Rule
 to determine the direction of the Coriolis Force is to 
1)
point your nose
 in the direction of the ocean current (or wind) is moving


2)
then stick your hand directly out from your side 
to get the direction of the Coriolis 
force – use the 
right hand
 for the northern hemisphere or use the 
left hand
 for the 
southern hemisphere

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Atmospheric Convection
1.
The warm ocean surface heats the 
atmosphere from below
 
2.
Warm surface air is able to hold a lot of 
water vapor and so it becomes moist.


3.
Warm moist surface air has low density so it 
rises (like a hot air balloon) and as it moves 
aloft it expands and cools


4.
Cooling of air aloft causes water vapor to 
condense and precipitate 


5.
Condensation releases latent heat that 
drives the upward convection even higher

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Question...
Background:
 The weight of a column of air is directly proportional to the average 
molecular weight of the mix of all molecules making up the air in the air column...


Assume dry air is mainly nitrogen gas (
N
2
 with a molecular weight of 
28
) with some 
variable amount of water vapor gas (
H
2
O
 with a molecular weight of 
18
) mixed in with it. 
Which Type of Air Column Produces the 
Lowest
 Sea Level Pressure?
 
a)
air column of 
dry air 
b)
air column with 
high amounts of water vapor
The 
correct answer is (b)
 since the average molecular weight of the mixture of 
molecules making up the air column is on average lower when overall fraction of 
water vapor gas is high.

Idealized Hadley 
Circulation
Low SLP
High SLP
High SLP
Low SLP
2.
Surface air at 30° spreads out north and south, warms and picks up moisture - by 60° latitude 
it has warmed and moistened to the point where it rises, cools, precipitates and spreads out 
aloft north/south. 


3.
Near the poles the air aloft becomes very cold and very dense so it sinks over the poles and 
spreads out toward the equator
SLP= Sea Level Pressure
1.
Surface air at the equator 
warms and rises aloft.  Air 
aloft spreads north/south 
and becomes more dense 
as it cools and dries (due 
to precipitation) and then 
sinks at about 30° latitude.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Global Sea Level Pressure Resulting from Idealized Hadley Circulation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Because sunlight energy is quickly absorbed in the ocean, all 
direct solar heating takes place very near the ocean 
surface     (0-30 meters).  


2.
Vertical mixing of near-surface water
 can move some of the 
warm water deeper, but mixing only reaches at most to about 
500 meters.  


3.
Seawater below 500 meters is uniformly cold.


4.
The broad region centered at around 500 meters where 
seawater temperature changes from warm to uniformly cold is 
referred to as the 
permanent thermocline
 


5.
In some ocean regions, there is a much shallower thermocline that 
only forms in summer and is then erased in winter. This temporary 
thermocline is referred to as the 
seasonal thermocline
Typical Vertical Profile 
of Temperature

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
In a stably stratified ocean, less dense water 
“floats” above more dense water.


2.
The 
seasonal pycnocline
 (region of strong 
change in density with depth) comes and goes 
with net heat gains in spring and summer and 
net heat losses in fall and winter


3.
The 
permanent pycnocline
 remains in place (at 
around 500 meters) and is the result of the long-
term balance between the downward heating/
mixing at the surface and upward mixing of cold 
water from below.
Typical Vertical Density 
Profile

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Main Heat Flux Components In 
and Out of the Surface Ocean
1.
Ocean temperature is a measure of the 
heat energy contained in the ocean.


2.
When more energy enters than leaves 
the ocean surface, the ocean surface 
warms. Similarly, when more heat 
leaves than enters the ocean surface, 
the ocean surface cools.
 
3.
Sunlight energy 
always adds heat to 
the ocean
 (during daylight hours).
4.
There are lots of ways to lose heat with Evaporative Cooling often being the dominant method of heat 
loss 


5.
For temperate (mid-latitude) ocean regions in spring/summer, more heat enters the ocean from 
sunlight than leaves to ocean and so the surface ocean warms.  In winter, more heat leaves 
than comes in from sunlight and the surface ocean cools

Ocean at Mid-Latitude Regions

Temperature
 and Surface 
Layer 
Thickness

© 2023 Bruce Monger
4.
Ekman Transport: 
is the rate of 
total water
 transported in the 
Ekman Layer (a layer that is 
about 50 to 100 meters thick) 
5.
Derived by summing all the individual thin currents sheets over the entire Ekman Layer


6.
Ekman Transport is exactly at 90 degrees from the wind direction


7.
Oceanographers often treat the Ekman Layer as a slab of water (i.e., the Ekman Layer) that 
moves in unison at 90 degrees to the right (northern hemisphere) or left (southern 
hemisphere) of the wind direct 
Ekman Layer
1.
Ekman Spiral
:  the spiraling of thin ocean 
currents within the Ekman Layer


2.
top-most current moves at 45-degrees to the 
wind forcing. Because of 
Wind+Coriolis+Friction  
3.
The bottom-most current moves directly 
opposite the wind direction. 
Ekman Transport Due to Wind Force, 
Friction Force and Coriolis Force

© 2023 Bruce Monger
3.
The fluid continues to be pushed by Coriolis until the Coriolis force is directed equal and opposite of the 
pressure gradient force - at which point the two forces cancel and the fluid move at steady speed (no 
acceleration) - remember too that there is no friction to bring this steady motion to a halt!


4.
The point at which currents move with steady speed with Coriolis and pressure gradient forces in prefect 
opposition is referred to as geostrophic balance and the resulting current is referred to as a 
geostrophic 
current
.
 
5.
Notice that 
fully developed geostrophic currents
 
move along lines of constant pressure
 (black lines in 
the figure above) 
1.
Fluid first responds to a 
pressure gradient force
 
(
blue arrow
) and moves down the pressure 
gradient toward lower pressure


2.
Coriolis force 
(
red arrow
) always pushes the fluid 
to the right of 
its present direction of travel
Top View of Horizontal Pressure Gradient
Response of Fluid in the Ocean Due to 
Pressure Gradient Force and Coriolis Force 
a simplified example here...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Development of the Subtropical Gyre in Response to 
Forcing by the Westerly and Trade Wind Belts
1.
Westerly and Trade Winds drive the Ekman Layer to 
the center of the gyre to create a mound of surface 
water 
2.
A center of high pressure develops under the mound of 
surface water.


3.
The fluid initially moves away from the center of high 
pressure


4.
the push of Coriolis turns the fluid until it travels 
along concentric lines of constant pressure - 
geostrophic balance 
5.
Note that Coriolis force always points toward the center 
of high pressure and in the northern hemisphere the right 
hand Coriolis rule then requires concentric clockwise 
motion to achieve a center directed Coriolis force.  
Counterclockwise motion is needed in the southern 
hemisphere with its left hand Coriolis Rule

Equatorial Upwelling
4.
Surface water also piles up on the western side of the ocean basin forcing a downward tilt to the 
thermocline


5.
Water is drawn up from the base to the [shallow] Ekman Depth.   
• If the thermocline is close the Ekman Depth, then cold water is drawn to the surface 
• if the thermocline is deep only more warm water is drawn to the surface 
1.
North East Trade Winds drive Ekman Transport 
of the surface layer 
to the north
 
2.
South East Trade Winds drive Ekman Transport 
of the surface layer 
to the south
 
3.
The “parting” of the surface water to the north 
and south requires, by continuity, that deep 
water rises upward from the base of the Ekman 
Layer to the surface along the Equator.
Ekman Layer Depth

2.
Western Equatorial 
Pacific Warm Pool -  
upwelling still occurs, but 
the thermocline is 
much deeper
 than the 
surface Ekman Depth so 
upwelling  just draws 
more warm water to the 
surface with no effective 
cooling.
1.
Eastern Equatorial Pacific Cold Tongue -  due to equatorial upwelling AND the 
close proximity of the thermocline to surface Ekman Depth

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Coastal Upwelling Along the 
Washington Oregon Coast
1.
Wind blowing out of the north drives the 
Ekman layer to the right (northern 
hemisphere) which is 
offshore


2.
The offshore transport of the Ekman 
surface layer is replaced by 
upwelling
 
of deeper cold water along the coast 


3.
Wind blowing out of the south drives 
the Ekman Layer again to the right 
(because northern hemisphere) which is 
onshore
4.
The onshore transport of the Ekman surface layer is driven downward - a process called 
downwelling

Deep water in the North Atlantic moves south and mergers with Antarctic water in the 
Southern Ocean as they both swing around Antarctica and up into the Indian and Pacific 
Ocean basin.

The oldest deep waters (c.a., 2000 years) are in the deep Pacific.

Cold dense water sinks in the North 
Atlantic and also around Antarctica to

North Pacific salinity is too low to 
sink even though temperatures are

3.
After giving up heat at high latitudes, surface water sinks and enters the thermohaline deep 
circulation and eventually is returned to the surface to pick up more heat and start the 
journey all over again. 
1.
Heat is gained by the surface ocean 
at low latitudes and transported via 
the wind-driven surface circulation 
(western boundary currents) to 
higher latitudes.


2.
Heat is given up by the ocean to 
the atmosphere at higher latitudes 
to warm these regions.
